awd_titl_txt: REU Site in Animal Behavior: mechanisms, cognition, and evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU site award to Indiana University, located in Bloomington, Indiana, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2015-2019. The site award is administered by the Center for the Integrative Study of Animal Behavior, a multidisciplinary group promoting the scientific understanding of animal behavior. Based on their interests, students will be matched with potential faculty mentors from a range of departments including Biology, Psychology, and Anthropology. In addition to obtaining intensive research experience, students receive training in research ethics, experimental design, how to present research, strategies in taking GRE tests, interview skills, and career options in science and education. The overall goal of these activities is to increase students' likelihood and ability to successfully enter graduate school or embark on a science-related career. Students from institutions with limited research opportunities and those from groups under-represented in science are especially encouraged to apply. Applications can be submitted via the online website listed below. 

It is anticipated that a total of 50 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. With guidance from a mentorship team, students will have the opportunity to perform and complete their own research projects-including designing experiments, collecting and analyzing data, and presenting their findings. Projects are typically in active areas of research, and students may go on to present their work at national meetings. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences), as well as focal groups and other events during the summer, will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available at http://www.indiana.edu/~animal/REU, or by contacting Linda Summers (812-855-9663 or cisab@indiana.edu) or the Program Director, Dr. Laura Hurley (812-856-1991 or lhurley@indiana.edu).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU award: ‘REU Site in Animal Behavior: mechanisms, cognition, and evolution’ trained 57 students in conducting research for a 10-week period, hosted by the Center for the Integrative Study of Animal Behavior at Indiana University Bloomington.

Intellectual merit: Interns in the program explored the ways that environmental factors affect the interactions between physiology and behavior. Studies were performed using model organisms and non-model organisms including free-living animals. Projects addressed different life stages, including juvenile and adult; compared males and females; focused on a range of behaviors such as reproduction, affiliation, aggression, and learning; and investigated mechanisms including gene expression, endocrine systems, neural systems, and microbiomes. For example, some studies explored how early-life experiences, including those induced by parental manipulation, influence endocrine setpoints and later adult behaviors in females versus males (birds, rodents). Others assessed the regulation of sensory-driven behaviors and memory by genetic and neuroendocrine mechanisms (insects, rodents, fish), or how host-parasite interactions are regulated by environmental factors and affect physiology and behavior (nematodes and haemosporidian parasites, insect and bird hosts). Evolutionary perspectives were gained through the comparison of similar physiological influences on behavior in multiple species with different degrees of relatedness.

Broader impacts: All interns also participated in extensive professional development in the areas of basic scientific skills (including experimental design, research ethics and animal welfare, statistical analysis, and presenting work in oral and written formats); demystifying academia (including sessions on networking and interviewing with faculty, impostor feelings, and life in graduate school); and graduate school preparedness (including finding graduate programs and mentors, writing personal statements, and interviewing). Graduate and postdoctoral mentors also received training in setting expectations, accountability, and communication. As a result of this work, 32 interns presented posters at institutional, regional, and national conferences, and 16 interns appeared as authors of peer-reviewed scientific journals. In longer-term outcomes, of students who replied to surveys asking about the importance of the REU experience to their careers, most said that the experience was important to their decision to go into a scientific discipline. For example, one former intern wrote: ‘Coming from a small, primarily undergraduate university, the REU program at IU set me up for success in graduate school. It taught me the skills that I needed to be competitive during the application process and made me a more confident and independent researcher. I was more prepared for my PhD program after completing my REU experience.’ Another student added: ‘This program was the first steppingstone in my career as a scientist. ..The Animal Behavior department community at IU always took extra care for us and has kept in contact with us after the completion of our program to help us advance in our careers. The program was designed to empower students, not (just) by teaching them how to do good research but also equip them with many professional development tools.’ Of 42 former interns whose next career steps could be determined, 26 (61.9%) entered graduate programs (PhD or Masters programs), 10 (23.8%) undertook training in medical fields (MD or public health programs), 2 (4.8%) entered veterinary training programs, and 4 (9.5%) took different paths such as conservation work for which postbaccalaureate training was not necessary.
